body: I agree that it doesn't make sense why all functionality is on admin, except that it probably evolved that way. In terms of proxying, we put an apache reverse proxy in front and a single rewrite rule. We need to specify `https://myapacheserver/admin` in order to get to the airflow server, but there isn't any issue with the other paths.

Hi!
What is `AIRFLOW__CORE__FERNET_KEY`? I don't see that being referenced anywhere in the code base? I'm only aware of setting the variable via the config file. What steps did you take to reproduce this? 

I will mention that if you had set the fernet key in the config and then edited a connection, the password would have been stored in the DB in encrypted form. If you, at some later point, removed the fernet key from your config file and set the ENV VAR, you will likely see the warming message though the password is encrypted in the DB.

If I understand your question, I believe that you are asking for Airflow to support setting config in the file and/or via ENV Vars. Is that what you are requesting?

+1 on the first approach. We need to have 2 types of users:
- Admin
- non-admin

Hi,

it's already possible to set config via environment variables. Quoting the Airflow documentation (http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/installation.html#configuration):

> You can also set options with environment variables by using this format: 
> $AIRFLOW__{SECTION}__{KEY} (note the double underscores).

Thus, to set the `fernet_key` option in the section `core`, I use `AIRFLOW__CORE__FERNET_KEY`, which works fine, cf. https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/configuration.py#L374.

The issue is that the `ConfigParserWithDefaults` class does not overwrite the `has_option` method of `ConfigParser` like it does with `get`. Hence, `alert_fernet_keys` (https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/www/views.py#L2096), which uses that method, knows nothing about the environment variables mechanism and emits the warning when the option is not set in the config file.
PR updated to include webhdfs proxy user support.

About semantics, `state` can be a little confusing as it is used for DagRun and TaskInstance and usually describes `failed`, `running`, `success`, ...

We might also allow to pause/unpause individual tasks in the future, so having two subcommands `airflow pause` and `airflow unpause` that could be used against DAGs or tasks may look better. Meaning we could evolved pause and unpause to support specifying a task regexp when we get there.
Nice. Thanks for taking the time.
FYI @askeys
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/948/files

Well there's actyally a 3rd option now with support for executable. The env vars seemed reasonable and apparently is a standard way to do things on the cloud. The "executing commands to get the stdout so we don't have to store the password in plaintext" thing came from Yahoo and apparently is a standard way of doing things there. That one I was more uneasy about but let it through. With the precedence rules it shouldn't get to that anyways.

With a good prefix `AIRFLOW__{section}__{key}` there's no risk of collision.

Well Airflow is built on top of flask-admin and leverages its templates and views. I'm unclear on where the /admin/admin/admin stuff is coming from, but it shouldn't occur. 

It may be sound to port the UI to `Flask App Builder` or even Django (much more of an undertaking) to get authentication and granular permissions / role management. I can't justify spending the time at this point though. 

If anyone can spare an intern, that's a pretty scoped out project with little need for guidance.
I like that idea, I will turn this into pause/unpause subcommands instead.

If we support the option of picking up configuration from multiple sources, then we need the functionality to allow admins or users to inspect the configuration that is being used on the webserver in order to see which config value wins in light of conflicts. This will avoid people pulling out their hair.

Currently, ConfigurationView only exposes the config in the `airflow.cfg` file and does not expose values pulled in from other sources, hence it will give a misleading impression of what configuration is being used. In the specific case of ENV VARS, which trump all other values, ConfigurationView will show the wrong value - i.e. the value from the config file which was trumped by the ENV VAR.

On a separate note, I only run Airflow on 1 machine. If folks are running multiple webservers and schedulers, there is an added complication of `airflow.cfg` differing on multiple machines.

```
class ConfigurationView(wwwutils.SuperUserMixin, BaseView):
    @expose('/')
    def conf(self):
        from airflow import configuration
        raw = request.args.get('raw') == "true"
        title = "Airflow Configuration"
        subtitle = configuration.AIRFLOW_CONFIG
        if configuration.getboolean("webserver", "expose_config"):
            with open(configuration.AIRFLOW_CONFIG, 'r') as f:
                config = f.read()
```

For the first issue, we should be able to update ConfigurationView to carry out conflict resolution and show winners. In order to solve the problem of multiple machines with different configuration, I don't have a quick solution.

Hmn.

@djeps
I am seeing something interesting on recent versions of Airflow which happens to be related to missing js. I first thought it was related to proxying, but when I went behind the proxy, I noticed the same problem at the server itself. I have an open issue for it at #881 

I wonder if you are seeing this issue as well.

I removed the dag_state for now. 

I can add a dag_status (naming?) later that mimics the dag index view in the UI if that is on the CLI roadmap.

:+1: 

Could be good to have a generic `desc` or `view` subcommand that would show all the details about a dag, task or task instance object. I use the UI for that but it can be great as you develop.

Sometime I'm thinking all the CLI features should be built on top of a REST interface, but we can get to that later.

I'm thinking that it might be relatively simple to handle this issue using the signal handler approach?

When the `gunicorn` process is launched, we record the PID in a variable and configure a signal handler using `signal.signal` to fire when airflow gets a `SIGTERM`. The signal handler calls `os.kill` with the PID that we saved earlier.
Or would setting `ExecStop` to `pkill -TERM -P $MAINPID` have the same effect?
So it looks like this is only failing due to coveralls. Any chance you could overlook that and merge it anyway? :)
It's failing because of the test are failing, I think you most likely forked at a bad time. Can you please rebase your branch, that will re-trigger the tests.

@plypaul the current state of this patch stores the PID in a file for the web server (gunicorn), as many others also do. This allows unicorn's own signal handler to pick up signals and reduces complexity in airflow. Ie. this patch already solves the issue for the web server. I'm working on the other parts which will require some adjustments or the addition of a signal handler. Hopefully I have a full patch at the end the week available.

Hi guys,

thanks for the fix. Our use case is exactly that we run Airflow in the cloud and don't want to have the Fernet key stored in a file.
We can close this @mistercrunch

The only missing `js` I'm seeing is `//admin/admin/admin/js/form-1.0.0.js` on "task duration, landing times and gantt" views. The problem with having another proxy just to have airflow properly proxied under it's own URI is that with our dockerized environment it makes little sense to have yet another container, but to fix the redirect to have airflow on it's own base url endpoint.

I think you're having issues with colliding versions of `flask-admin`. You can try `pip uninstall flask-admin`, and/or `sudo pip uninstall flask-admin` before reinstalling the pinned version from setup.py (`pip install flask-admin==1.4.0`)

If you use a virtualenv you can start from a fresh, clean one.
There's an endpoint though, so it should be trivial to add a button.
Thanks for the detailed report. That's clearly a bug.

Well, it's a little more complicated for the user to manage PID files, so I was looking to see if there were a simpler solution. With the signal handler approach, gunicorn will still get the same signals.
Gentle nudge here. :)
Here you go : https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/956

Interesting. Did you `pip install` the release or `git pull` from the repo and run `python setup.py install`? I'd like to reproduce this. if the latter, can you show me the output of your `git log` command?

I think I have my answer. We are not even running this in our staging or production environment. The `First run` message was introduced into the code on `1/19/2016`

```
sid-as-mbp:airflow siddharth$ git blame models.py  | grep "First run"
695bb010 airflow/models.py  (Maxime Beauchemin      2016-01-19 22:04:21 -0800  982)                 msg = "First run"
```

The commit that introduced this change was a fix to the infinite retry bug I had reported : 

```
commit 695bb010a16a1caa6673a0147b8c558b7efaab1e
Author: Maxime Beauchemin <maximebeauchemin@gmail.com>
Date:   Tue Jan 19 22:04:21 2016 -0800

    [hotfix] fixing infinite retries in prod

diff --git a/airflow/models.py b/airflow/models.py
index 08e93b4..030e28f 100644
--- a/airflow/models.py
+++ b/airflow/models.py
@@ -946,15 +946,13 @@ class TaskInstance(Base):
             )
         elif force or self.state in State.runnable():
             HR = "\n" + ("-" * 80) + "\n"  # Line break
-            if self.state == State.UP_FOR_RETRY:
-                msg = (
-                    "Retry run {self.try_number} out of {task.retries} "
-                    "starting @{iso}")
-                self.try_number += 1
+            tot_tries = task.retries + 1
+            if self.try_number == 1:
+                msg = "First run"
             else:
-                msg = "New run starting @{iso}"
-                self.try_number = 1
+                msg = "Retry {self.try_number} out of {tot_tries}"
             msg = msg.format(**locals())
+            self.try_number = 1
             logging.info(HR + msg + HR)
             self.start_date = datetime.now()
```
Actually, I do require the output of your `git log` command if you have it. I'll try to reproduce on HEAD master, but just looking at the code, it doesn't look like the bug still exists.
Do you guys use dag_ids with digits as first char? I was thinking I'd remove support for them in `utils.validate_key`.

@dventimi Maybe if you run `airflow resetdb` it will work. It worked for me at least.
Thanks, I just reproduced it on HEAD master.
This might also be related https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/726
+1 on my end

`@daily`, the other `@` shortcuts and the cron notation subscribe to the standard of having a clear schedule, and `execution_date` that line up. I'd rather phase out the support for time interval support than allowing for it on the cron notation side.

The better way to delay tasks is with data dependencies (sensors!) or a TimeDeltaSensor in the absence of it. 

Changing the schedule, especially while having `depends_on_past=True` will lead to all sorts of confusing clogging. The key is to move the start_date to something on your schedule.

An eventual `DAG.validate` method could check that start_dates fall onto an existing schedule, or something rounded when using timedeltas.

Thanks for reporting this -- this is now fixed and awaiting merge. Once merged, please verify and close.

The query that currently backs statuses column is equivalent to:

```
SELECT ti.dag_id, ti.state, COUNT(ti.task_id)
FROM task_instance ti
GROUP BY 1, 2;
```

In my proposal this becomes:

```
SELECT ti.dag_id, ti.state, COUNT(task_id)
FROM task_instance ti
LEFT JOIN (
    SELECT dag_id, execution_date FROM dag_run WHERE dag_run.state = 'running'
) active ON ti.dag_id = active.dag_id AND ti.execution_date = active.execution_date
LEFT JOIN (
    SELECT dag_id, MAX(execution_date) AS execution_date FROM dag_run GROUP BY dag_id
) recent ON ti.dag_id = recent.dag_id AND ti.execution_date = recent.execution_date
WHERE active.dag_id IS NOT NULL
OR recent.dag_id IS NOT NULL
GROUP BY 1, 2;
```
Correct. The provisioning can be done by the files no need to encapsulate it in the test itself.

Hi!
`Dependencies Not Met` implies that some pre-conditions for a run to be scheduled were not met.  

http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/_modules/airflow/models.html#TaskInstance.are_dependencies_met

For example, if a previous day's run did not complete successfully and if your DAG were not to specify ``depends_on_past': True` as shown in the example below:

```
default_args = {
    'owner': 'sanand',
    'depends_on_past': True,
    'pool': 'ep_data_pipeline',
    'start_date': START_DATE,
    'email': [import_ep_pipeline_alert_email_dl],
    'email_on_failure': import_airflow_enable_notifications,
    'email_on_retry': import_airflow_enable_notifications,
    'retries': 1,
    'retry_delay': timedelta(seconds=120),
    'priority_weight': import_airflow_priority_weight
}
dag = DAG(DAG_NAME, schedule_interval='@hourly', default_args=default_args, sla_miss_callback=sla_alert_func)
```

Then, my executing `airflow run my_dag my_task 2016-02-07` would show the above error if  `airflow run my_dag my_task 2016-02-06` did not complete successfully.

It would help if you could provide a detailed example of your issue, so I could better answer it or determine if there were some buggy behavior.

Refer to comments in the submitted PR! This is specific to task_regex and dry-run in backfill. If you remove either of dry_run or task_regex, it will work. Still, I have submitted a fix for review.

This line is on purpose to allow deepcopying DAG objects that have `params` and `default_args` that can't be deepcopied. The reason why this hack is there when we migrated to Airflow we did so from another tool that had non-deepcopyable objects and added this to support an easy migration. Ultimately I want a `DAG.validate()` method that enforces certain checks, one of which is making sure the DAG can be deep-copied.

So what about this approach instead, right before `return results`:

```
results.params = self.params
results.user_defined_macros = self.user_defined_macros
```

This will result in not copying these two attributes, and hard linking them instead which is fine in this context.
